results.title: You don't fool me
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Social Psychology”.
Shows how a social psychological experiment is designed, conducted and analysed. The experiment is a test to see if non-verbal behaviour gives clues as to whether a person is being deceptive - the hypothesis being that the face will not give clues to deception, but the hands and feet will. One of a series of a third level course from the Faculty of Social Science Open University. The purpose is to provide insight into social behaviour and experience. The essential focus is on theories, findings, and methods of social psychology.

results.title: Analysing interaction No.1 (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Nell Smith, BBC and Open University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Social Psychology”.
Shows an interaction sequence between a young man (Russ) and an older woman (Angela) who meet at a party. This sequence is then analysed by seven different psychologists and sociologists who adapt different orientations. Three of the analyses are presented in the first part. Suitable for Mid-Upper Secondary School level.

results.title: Understanding aggro/hooliganism
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Social Psychology”.
Research into the origins and forms of soccer hooliganism. It is a vehicle for the younger generation to find excitement, including ritualised violence. Presented by Dr George Gaskell.

results.title: Psychosexual differences. No. 2
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Social Psychology”.
Looks at the physiological and genetic origins of sexually differentiated behaviour. Jeffrey Grey talks about his research with rats and the kind of role reversals he can initiate by the manipulation of hormones.

results.title: Naughty things (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Carol Haslam, BBC and Open University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Social Psychology”.
Presents separate interviews with four young children, which are intended to illustrate Jean Piaget’s methods of clinical investigation and his conclusions about the moral development of children contained in his book entitled “Le Jugement moral chez l’enfant”. Introduction by Derek Wright.

results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Social Psychology”.
Two interviews with a businessman approaching the end of his successful career and an occupant of a rural commune to study the differences between them and how they relate to the themes in the unit being studied, ie the Social Science Course.

results.title: Identity
results.creator_credit: Michael Philps, Victor Lockwood, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Social Psychology”.
One of a series of a third level course from the Faculty of Social Science, Open University. The purpose is to provide insight into social behaviour and experience focussing on theories, findings and methods of social psychology. In this episode Norman Leighton, a young artist who grew up in the East End of London, talks about his youth and his art.

results.title: Early interactions (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Michael Philps, Victor Lockwood, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Social Psychology”.
H.R. Schaffer introduces five experiments which demonstrate the importance of synchronisation between mother and baby. The experiments also show that it is often the baby who initiates the interactions.

results.title: Working to a system
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Small Business”.
Production problems in the smaller business are of two main types: getting the most from existing resources and gearing production for expansion. Both are examined and advice is given on meeting some of the special difficulties likely when mechanisation is introduced, on management controls, the use of charts for production planning and order processing.
